infodynamics.measures.continuous
Interface ChannelCalculatorCommon

All Known Subinterfaces:
ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateWithMarginals, TransferEntropyCalculator, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate
All Known Implementing Classes:
MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskovByMulti, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskovByMulti1, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskovByMulti2, MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlain, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelPlainIterators, TransferEntropyCalculatorKernelSeparate, TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskovByMulti, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKraskovByMulti, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel, TransferEntropyCalculatorSymbolic, TransferEntropyCommon
public interface ChannelCalculatorCommon

An abstract interface for calculators computing measures from a source to a destination.

The interface is abstract because further specification is required for addObservations or setObservations methods showing whether this is a univariate or multivariate measure.

Author:
Joseph Lizier, email, www

computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

Computes the local values of the implemented channel measure, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

If disjoint observations were supplied using several calls such as ChannelCalculator.addObservations(double[], double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single return array, though of course the time series for these disjoint observations were not appended in computing the required PDFs).

Returns:
array of local values.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

computeSignificance

EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception

Compute the significance of obtaining the given average measure from the given observations.

This is as per Chavez et. al., "Statistical assessment of nonlinear causality: application to epileptic EEG signals", Journal of Neuroscience Methods 124 (2003) 113-128.

Basically, we shuffle the source observations against the destination tuples. This keeps the marginal PDFs the same (including the entropy rate of the destination) but destroys any correlation between the source and state change of the destination.

Parameters:
numPermutationsToCheck - number of new orderings of the source values to compare against
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

computeSignificance

EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception

As per computeSignificance() but supplies the re-orderings of the observations of the source variables.

Parameters:
newOrderings - first index is permutation number, i.e. newOrderings[i] is an array of 1 permutation of 0..n-1, where there were n observations. If the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to numObservations, an Exception is thrown.
Returns:
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
